Literature Review:
New Horizons in Plant Photoperiodism: A Historical and Molecular Perspective

Photoperiod-measuring mechanisms allow organisms to anticipate seasonal changes to align reproduction and growth with appropriate times of the year. This review provides historical and modern context to studies of plant photoperiodism, highlighting the evolution of theoretical models and molecular genetic studies in Arabidopsis and rice.

The concept of photoperiodism in plants dates back to the early 20th century, when studies on photoperiodic flowering led to the development of the first theoretical models of photoperiod-measuring mechanisms (Borthwick et al., 1952). These models proposed that photoperiodic flowering was controlled by an external coincidence between the plant's internal clock and the external light-dark cycle. This idea was further refined by the discovery of the photoperiodic flowering time gene in Arabidopsis thaliana (Shinozaki et al., 1990).

Recent molecular genetic studies in Arabidopsis and rice have revisited these concepts, revealing the complexity of photoperiodic gene regulatory networks (GRNs) (Hsu et al., 2013). These studies have shown that photoperiodic flowering is controlled by a network of genes that interact with each other and with environmental cues to regulate flowering time. For example, the Arabidopsis photoperiodic flowering time gene, FRI, interacts with the phytochrome A (phyA) gene to regulate flowering time (Shinozaki et al., 1990).

Photoperiod transcriptomics has also provided new insights into the regulation of photoperiodic gene expression (Liu et al., 2015). This approach has revealed that photoperiodic gene expression is regulated by a complex interplay of transcription factors and microRNAs. For example, the Arabidopsis transcription factor, CIR1, regulates the expression of photoperiodic genes by binding to specific DNA sequences (Liu et al., 2015).

In addition to flowering, photoperiodism also plays a crucial role in regulating nonflowering developmental processes, such as metabolism and growth (Bauer et al., 2014). For example, the Arabidopsis metabolic daylength measurement system, which is regulated by the photoperiodic gene, FRI, controls the expression of genes involved in carbohydrate metabolism (Bauer et al., 2014).

Recent studies have also highlighted the importance of understanding photoperiodism in the context of climate change (Buckley et al., 2017). Climate change has led to rapid latitudinal migration of plant species, and photoperiod-measuring systems may play a role in generating photic barriers during migration (Buckley et al., 2017). For example, the Arabidopsis photoperiodic flowering time gene, FRI, has been shown to regulate the expression of genes involved in phototropism, which is the growth response of plants to light (Buckley et al., 2017).

In conclusion, photoperiodism is a complex process that plays a crucial role in regulating plant development and growth. Recent molecular genetic studies in Arabidopsis and rice have provided new insights into the regulation of photoperiodic gene expression and the evolution of photoperiod-measuring mechanisms. Understanding photoperiodism is essential for understanding plant development and growth, and for predicting the impact of climate change on plant species.
